results.title: Together in the middle of nowhere
results.creator_credit: Rachel Clements, Tony Krawitz and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Vince embarks on an odyssey through the city streets while his girlfriend Jacqui works in a stripclub until dawn. Over one night they journey into the darkness of their own hearts to find out what really matters. Cast includes Mark Priestley as Vince and Hayley McElhinney as Jacqui

results.title: Carmen de Sevilla
results.creator_credit: William C. Faure and English Television Drama
results.brief_description: Based on the opera “Carmen” by Georges Bizet and on the original production by the Performing Arts Council of the Transvaal, the Mercedes Molina Spanish Dance Theatre combine flamenco with traditional ballet to present this theatrical performance for television. Features Mercedes Molina as Carmen and Enrique Segovia as Jose.

results.title: Carmen
results.creator_credit: Gavin Taylor, Ken Scorfield, Classical Productions and Allied Vision
results.brief_description: The lavish and spectacular television production of Georges Bizet’s “Carmen”, staged at London’s Earls Court in June 1989, proved beyond doubt the resounding success of opera on such a grand scale. Playing to sell-out audiences of over twelve thousand at each performance, the production drew rave reviews from all the critics. Starring Maria Ewing, who has now made this part her own, “Carmen” was staged in the centre of Earls Court, surrounded on all sides by the audience to create the atmosphere of a Spanish bullring.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gavin Taylor, Ken Scorfield, Classical Productions and Allied Vision

results.title: Carlton New Wave: Question and Answer Session
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
ACMI’s ‘Australian Perspectives’ film season frames contemporary Australian filmmaking against a backdrop of archival classics and special guest presentations.
This question and answer session with a panel of Australian film industry figures, was held on Saturday 7th September 2013 as Part 2 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’, following a screening of Nigel Buesst’s 1971 film ‘Bonjour Balwyn’.
Hosted by Rochelle Siemienowicz, the panel included Nigel Buesst, Peter Hourigan, Alan Finney and John Flaus.
The discussion highlights the key role of Melbourne, and Carlton in particular, as a centre for independent filmmaking in the 1960s and 1970s. The memories and anecdotes recounted by the panellists illustrate the vibrancy and creative energy of the Melbourne scene and the socio-economic context that allowed it to flourish.
NOTE: Part 1 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’ was an August 2013 screening of Brian Davies’ 1966 film ‘Pudding Thieves’.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Kenneally, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: Carlton + Godard = cinema [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Nigel Buesst and Sunrise Picture Company
results.brief_description:
A retrospective look at the film-making movement in Carlton during the 1960s/1970s, the filmmakers and the influences that inspired and motivated them. Includes an examination of the life and work of neo-realist Giorgio Mangiamele, and the French new wave styles of Brian Davies, Peter Carmody, Antony I. Ginnane, Peter Elliot, James Clayden, Nigel Buesst, David Minter. An assembly of extracts from several of the Carlton films are juxtaposed with pieces of Godard’s early films revealing much about a fascinating period of Melbourne filmmaking.
Features Antony I. Ginnane, Geoffrey Gardner, James Clayden, Bob Garlick, Giancarlo Giusti, Graeme Cutts. Narrated by Peter Fisher.

results.title: Caring for our country
results.brief_description: Examines three major environmental problems with regards to land use. These are salinity, soil erosion and tree decline. The video explores the ways in which today’s farmers take responsibility for land degradation and the strategies they use to deal with these problems.

results.title: Cardio funk aerobics at the Dome with Marcus Irwin
results.creator_credit: Mark Thorn and J T V Productions
results.brief_description: Since Marcus Irwin introduced ‘Cardio Funk’ to Australia in 1989 it has become one of the most popular forms of Aerobics. Marcus and his fluorescent entourage begin this intermediate workout with a ten minute instructional segment and will guide through a routine which includes a warm up to prepare your body for the workout, a section aimed at co-ordinating, your arms and legs and gradually raises your workout level, a cardiovascular section, a ‘Jammin’ segment which combines the various steps and finally a ‘cool down’ to end your session.
